introduction.p: Suppose you have a collection of mathematical objects. The objects in the collection may satisfy all/some/none of the following rules, depending on the objects. In the rule statements, bold variable letters represent arbitrary objects in the collection, and ordinary variable letters represent arbitrary scalars ( numbers).

ol.li: The objects can be added (two at a time), and the resulting sum is always equal to another in the collection of objects.
There is a special zero object in the collection, so that every \uvec{v} satisfies \uvec{v}+\zerovec=\uvec{v}.
Every \uvec{v} has an opposite \widetilde{\uvec{v}} so that \uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}}=\zerovec.
The objects can be scaled by a numerical factor (called a scalarscalar), and the resulting scaled object is always equal to another in the collection of objects.

statement.p: Read and briefly discuss the rules in your group. In particular, make sure everyone in your group understands the differences between the LHS and RHS in each of Rule A, Rule A, Rule S, Rule S, and Rule S.
It may help to come up with expressions for these algebra rules in plain English rather than letters and variables. For example, Rule A states that order doesn't matter in adding objects.

These rules are modelled on the properties of vectors in \R^n. Convince yourself that all the rules are true when the collection of mathematical objects considered is all vectors in \R^2. In particular, make sure you know what the zero object is in the collection Rule A), and how to find an object's opposite Rule A).

For each of the following collections of objects, convince yourself that all the rules are true. In particular, make sure you know what the zero object is in the collection, and how to find an object's opposite.
All 2\times 2 matrices.
All m\times n matrices. (Here m and n are some specific but unknown numbers.)
All polynomials in the variable x.
All polynomials in the variable x of degree 2 or less ( no x^3 or higher allowed).
All real numbers. Careful
In the last example collection, both objects and scalars are numbers. Don't get mixed up!

Suppose you have a collection of objects that satisfies all of the rules. (Don't pick a specific example collection, just think in the abstract.)
For an object \uvec{v}, is it necessarily always true that \zerovec + \uvec{v} = \uvec{v}?
Look at Rule A and Rule A.
For an object \uvec{v} and its opposite \widetilde{\uvec{v}}, is it necessarily always true that \widetilde{\uvec{v}} + \uvec{v} = \zerovec?
Look at Rule A and Rule A.
By Rule A, an object \uvec{v} has an opposite \widetilde{\uvec{v}}, which itself is an object. What is the opposite of \widetilde{\uvec{v}}? Make sure you can justify that your answer satisfies the definition of opposite contained in Rule A.
Suppose \uvec{v} is an object. What object do you think 0\uvec{v} should be equal to? Do the rules provide direct evidence to support your guess?
Here is a justification of your guess from the previous part of this activity. (Assuming you guessed correctly!) Fill in the blanks with the identifier of the rule that justifies each step, working down the left-hand side first. Make sure you understand how and for what objects that rule is being applied.
\uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}} \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp \amp 0\uvec{v}+(1\uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}}) \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp
1\uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}} \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp \amp 0\uvec{v}+(\uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}}) \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp
(0+1)\uvec{v}+\widetilde{\uvec{v}} \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp\text{(arithmetic)} \amp 0\uvec{v}+\zerovec \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp
(0\uvec{v}+1\uvec{v})+\widetilde{\uvec{v}} \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp \amp 0\uvec{v} \amp= \zerovec \amp \amp
Use the rules to simplify the expression \uvec{v} + (-1)\uvec{v}. Make sure each step is justified by a specific rule, similarly to the previous part of this activity. Note
As well as the rules from the top of this activity set, you may also use your newly justified rule from the previous part of this activity set. This is a useful pattern: every time we use existing rules to create a new rule, that new rule can be freely used to help create even more rules.
Start by using Rule S backwards, like in the first step in the previous part of this activity.
Take \uvec{v} + (-1)\uvec{v} = X, where X is your final simplified expression from the previous part of this activity. We can cancel the \uvec{v} from the LHS by adding \widetilde{\uvec{v}} to both sides of the equality. Based on the resulting equality after doing that, what do you think is a better name for \widetilde{\uvec{v}} than opposite of \uvec{v}?

Nominate one member of your group to become an object, and consider the collection of objects that consists of just one object (namely, the group member you nominated).
Can you come up with some sort of addition so that Rule A is true?
Can you come up with some sort of scaling operation so that axiom Rule S is true? If so, continue on and check whether the other axioms are true with your operations.
